subject: Re: [junit] Unit Testing vs Integration Testing

messageBody:
Mike,

I think that they're both valuable (and necessary), mostly because they
test different things.

My unit tests guarantee that the small parts of my code work the way I
expect them to, and enforce the contracts of the API I'm providing. I
can test code that interacts with other systems even before those other
systems exist, so long as we've defined their API. Its important,
however, to limit the scope of your unit tests to things that *you* are
responsible for. If you miss that, you'll end up writing
unit-integration tests, that I find become unwieldy fairly quickly.

What I've noticed in my integration testing is that now that I use unit
tests, finding the actual problems that crop up during integration
testing takes much less time. Whereas before all I knew was "the
webpage does NOT appear" and I had a forest of reasons why that could
be, now I know from my unit tests that large parts of the system are
working, and the problem must be somewhere in the 'seams'.

Actually, I'd say that leads me to the opposite of your hunch that "the
cost-per-bug-eliminated of unit testing is higher than that of
integration testing", because there's generally a long period of time
in the integration test between bug discovery and bug repair, where in
my unit tests, its quite small. I suppose I'd also disagree that the
two take the same amount of time to construct, as I'm a true believer
(tm) that writing unit tests at the same time as your code takes the
same time as writing your code without unit tests and testing by hand.
In both those cases you still have to go through integration tests when
you're done.

Lastly, the advantages in cleanup of your API (if it isn't easlity
testable, it may not be easily usable) are, to me at least, very real
and significant.

Just to be clear, I still integration test, too. It just tends to go
smoother, and I have better knowledge of where the problem is.

This obviously wasn't a scientific study paper, but hopefully its a
helpful perspective.

Kevin

--- Mike Bresnahan <java-junit@...> wrote:
> I have experience with integration testing but not much with unit
> testing.
> I've been reading up on unit testing (e.g. mock objects, test first
> development). However, I have not found an article that explains the
> advantages of unit testing vs integration testing. My perhaps naive
> hunch
> is that the cost-per-bug-eliminated of unit testing is higher than
> that of
> integration testing. It appears this way because a single
> integration test
> tests a lot more code than a single unit test and takes about the
> same
> amount of time to construct. Plus it seems to me that a whole suite
> of unit
> tests with 100% code coverage cannot guarantee that even the simplest
> system
> wide behavior is correct (e.g. the web page appears). Am I wrong
> about
> this? Can someone refer me information about this topic. A
> scientific
> study paper with real numbers would be welcome.
>
> Mike Bresnahan
